page.title: 06Dairy and sheep in Evie
page.content: Fresian is the main breed of dairy cow although a few Ayrshires are kept. The cows are milked regularily, once at about 0600hrs and again at about 1700hrs. Some dairy farms milk in tied byres, the milk being piped to their dairies. However herring-bone parlours are becoming more common. At peak production cows will yield an average of about 34 litres per day. This milk is taken by tanker to the Claymore Creamery where it is pastur- ised and bottled for sale or made into 'Orkney Cheese'. Milk quotas have caused an increase in sheep numbers on dairy farms. Beef and dairy farms commonly use Shetland/Cheviot ewes sired by a Suffolk ram. Lambing is usually in spring and the lambs are sold locally the following October. A few farms house their sheep over the winter.
